Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was sitting on the couch, phone in hand, scrolling through possible dinner spots for Maya and me. We’d both finally found a week with free evenings, and she’d been excitedly texting me about trying that new Italian place. I could almost hear her laughter, see her eyes light up across the table. Just as I was about to call her, my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from the activist group. A major news network wanted me on air tonight, right now, to counter a wave of misinformation about our cause. My heart pounded. I knew how much Maya valued our time together, how she’d been looking forward to this after weeks of us missing each other. But I also knew how crucial it was to speak up, to set the record straight before the public latched onto the wrong story. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, caught between the person I love and the cause I believe in.
